App description:
Swords of Gargantua is a VR sword-action game you can experience in single-player mode or online co-op with up to 3 other players.

Traverse through the Tesseract Abyss floors with the aim of taking down the giant Gargantua in its deepest layer, Floor 101. 

Make use of various weapons and abilities which you earn with every attempt, and take on difficult battles along your journey. A wide variety of weapons are available, allowing you to pursue your own virtual reality action (one and two-handed swords, axes, maces, boomerangs, shields, etc.)

While playing, you can use voice chat to communicate with your fellow warriors while taking on the enemies in Tesseract Abyss or join up to 8 players in a lounge for pre or post-game hangouts.

Pros, Cons & Improvements

First off, I really enjoy the crazy hectic sword battles I quite often find myself in in this game. Trying to parry, block, dodge and counterattack against multiple enemies is incredibly fun! I would recommend having a textile surface in the middle of your playspace, with enough space to swing your arms around crazily as you WILL lose track of your positioning otherwise (punched my wall a few times haha)


Pros:

- Sword play is engaging and fun, with a decent learning curve involved for both the fight mechanics and the enemy movements.
- Single Player progression is satisfying, with a good tutorial process, which initially tells you all you need to know without making it too easy
- Multiplayer is fun when you can find teammates to join up with and is a necessary element when trying to play the higher levels
- Sword physics are progressively improving, so it's nice the Devs are still actively working on it
- Events organised by the Devs occur regularly in-game and on social media which can reward players with new and unique weapons to use
- Voice chat works well and as of yet I've had no issues communicating with other players (although better hand gestures would be nice)


Cons:

- Only one weapon can be equipped at a time, meaning no personalised builds such as dual wielding or shield & sword
- Weapons and shields picked up during gameplay have no visible health bar and cannot be attached to your avatar or repaired
- Cannot customise your in-game avatar or armour design/colour
- Sword physics are decent, but will often get caught and stuck on objects or just not track very well. I find myself just doing overhead downward hammer swings most of the time
- Enemy attacks will often ignore your blocks because of how close they position themselves to you (unless you spend the entire game moving backwards during fights)
- Projectiles are not easy to master or even understand. Some throws feel auto-locked whereas others go off at random tangents
- AI teammates are completely useless in end-game because they have no ability to dodge unblockable attacks, revive other AI, utilise power ups or prioritise objectives
- Picking up items is frustrating and not at all intuitive, as the line projecting from your hand does so at an awkward angle and also disappears immediately from sight
- Not many multiplayer levels to play through yet

Improvements:

- Improve weapon tracking to allow for faster/more intricate combat when up against multiple combatants
- Add an additional weapon slot over our shoulder for off-hand weapons such as shields/shuriken/nunchuks, even if these weapons aren't repaired while holstered it would nice
- Let us choose from a select number of colour options for our avatar's armour
- Program the AI to not actively move into the path of unblockable attacks (such as Gargantua ground slams) and to also revive other AI
- More multiplayer events as opposed to single player, as matchmaking is always an issue. Having more people actively engaged in the servers would be nice
- Map finger tracking to the controllers so that the use of more hand gestures is possible


Hopefully more people get into this game, as it's best enjoyed with teammates you can communicate/coordinate with.

I was afraid this would become a "parry game", but it actually strikes a good balance between offense and defense. You swing harder to do more damage so "Hand Wiggling" won't works here. Enemies telegraph their attacks very clearly, so you know when to step back into defense. Developing a tactic for attack and parry bring depth into the experience.

After successful parrying enemy exposes "weak point", but the window for riposte is pretty short, so determine between rapid riposte or aiming for weak point create another healthy skill ceiling. However the parry hitbox is confusing sometimes, especially for lower attacks. It's hard to tell why my parry fail. Maybe it's a bug, or maybe it's just a tricky action to perform in real world as well.

One unique mechanic in this game is to use your full body to dodge. It has a cooldown so you can't spam it by jumping back and forth. This is just enough to make me engage with full body movement but not too exhaustive like some boxing game.

The game loop is very simple. You enter a level and enemies spawn in pre-determined patterns, and you kill them all and go to the next level. There are currently 100 levels. This is simple yet very effective, as new weapons unlock with later level, and the "Star" system increase replayability.

The weapon breaking system, however, is a questionable design choice. It's a way to force player to try out different weapons, but other than that I don't find it add anything to the experience.
